1910.1200 Hazard Communication
1910.1200 Hazard Communication

Purpose of OSHA’s Hazard Communication Standard
Purpose of OSHA’s Hazard
Communication Standard

To ensure that employers and employees know about work hazards and how to protect themselves so that the incidence of illnesses and injuries due to hazardous chemicals is reduced.
To ensure that employers and employees know
about work hazards and how to protect themselves
so that the incidence of illnesses and injuries due to
hazardous chemicals is reduced.

Hazard Communication Program
Hazard
Communication
Program

Container Labeling

Labeling

Data Sheet

Program

MSDS

Employer Responsibilities
Employer Responsibilities

• Identify and list hazardous chemicals in their
• Identify and list hazardous chemicals in their

workplaces
workplaces

• Obtain Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) and
• Obtain Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) and

labels for each hazardous chemical, if not provided by the manufacturer, importer, or distributor
labels for each hazardous chemical, if not provided
by the manufacturer, importer, or distributor

• Implement a written HazCom program, including
• Implement a written HazCom program, including

labels, MSDSs, and employee training
labels, MSDSs, and employee training

• Communicate hazard information to employees through labels, MSDSs, and formal training programs
• Communicate hazard information to employees
through labels, MSDSs, and formal training
programs

How can workplace hazards be minimized?
How can workplace hazards be minimized?

• The first step in minimizing workplace
• The first step in minimizing workplace

hazards is to perform a thorough hazard assessment
hazards is to perform a thorough hazard
assessment

• Employers can rely on the evaluations performed by the manufacturers or importers to establish the hazards of the chemicals they use – This information is obtained from MSDSs and labels
• Employers can rely on the evaluations
performed by the manufacturers or
importers to establish the hazards of the
chemicals they use
– This information is obtained from MSDSs and labels

Requirements

• Describes container labeling, MSDSs,
• Describes container labeling, MSDSs,

and employee training for each workplace
and employee training for each
workplace

• List of the hazardous chemicals • Make information regarding hazards and protective measures available to other employers onsite
• List of the hazardous chemicals
• Make information regarding hazards and
protective measures available to other
employers onsite

How must chemicals be labeled?
How must chemicals be labeled?

Each container of hazardous chemicals entering the workplace must be labeled or marked with: • Identity of the chemical • Appropriate hazard
Each container of hazardous
chemicals entering the workplace
must be labeled or marked with:
• Identity of the chemical
• Appropriate hazard

warnings
warnings

• Name and address of the
• Name and address of the

responsible party
responsible party

area

• Physical hazards, such as fire and explosion • Health hazards, such as signs of exposure • Routes of exposure • Precautions for safe handling and use • Emergency and first-aid procedures • Control measures

Summary
Summary

• OSHA’s Hazard Communication
• OSHA’s Hazard Communication

Standard is based on a simple concept - that employees have both a need and a right to know the hazards and identities of the chemicals they are exposed to when working
Standard is based on a simple concept -
that employees have both a need and a
right to know the hazards and identities
of the chemicals they are exposed to
when working

• Employees also need to know what protective measures are available to prevent adverse effects from occurring
• Employees also need to know what
protective measures are available to
prevent adverse effects from occurring

Related Work Activities
Related Work Activities

• Applying pesticides and other chemicals • Cutting concrete, brick • Spraying paint • Applying mulch, peat and other organics • Clearing heavy brush • Trimming, cutting heavy undergrowth

substances

Dermatitis (Skin Irritation)
Dermatitis (Skin Irritation)

Pesticide Exposures
Pesticide Exposures

• Dermal – Getting pesticide on your skin • Inhalation – Breathing in pesticide • Oral – Swallowing pesticide • Ocular – Getting pesticide in the eyes
• Dermal – Getting pesticide on your skin
• Inhalation – Breathing in pesticide
• Oral – Swallowing pesticide
• Ocular – Getting pesticide in the eyes

Preventing Skin Irritation From Chemicals
Preventing Skin Irritation
From Chemicals

• Know what substances you are using • Read MSDS for the chemical • Read the chemical label • Avoid contact with strong chemical irritants • Use PPE • Launder clothing after handling pesticides. • Wash exposed body parts often to reduce
• Know what substances you are using
• Read MSDS for the chemical
• Read the chemical label
• Avoid contact with strong chemical irritants
• Use PPE
• Launder clothing after handling pesticides.
• Wash exposed body parts often to reduce

dermal exposure.
dermal exposure.

Preventing Silica Exposure
Preventing Silica Exposure

• Use a substitute for silica • Use engineering controls to reduce exposure • Improve work practices • Use personal protective equipment

• Use engineering controls to reduce exposure

• Use personal protective equipment

Spray Painting
Spray Painting

• May occur during building or equipment
• May occur during building or equipment

maintenance.
maintenance.

• Spraying paint at a worksite exposes
• Spraying paint at a worksite exposes

workers to hazardous vapors.
workers to hazardous vapors.

• Paint vapors can also be explosive. • Workers must take safety precautions to minimize their exposure to those vapors.
• Paint vapors can also be explosive.
• Workers must take safety precautions to
minimize their exposure to those vapors.

Reducing Exposure to Vapors
Reducing Exposure to Vapors

• Ventilation
• Ventilation

– Spray painting outside may help to reduce
– Spray painting outside may help to reduce

exposure to vapors
exposure to vapors

– Local exhaust ventilation when indoors • Wear a respirator if engineering controls
– Local exhaust ventilation when indoors
• Wear a respirator if engineering controls

fail.
fail.

Dust and Mold
Dust and Mold

• Landscaping and horticultural work often involve peat, vermiculite, perlite, and mulch.
• Landscaping and horticultural work often
involve peat, vermiculite, perlite, and
mulch.

• Exposure to mold can cause respiratory
• Exposure to mold can cause respiratory

• Greenhouses and nurseries particularly
• Greenhouses and nurseries particularly

disease.
disease.

susceptible.
susceptible.

Reducing Exposure To Dust And Mold
Reducing Exposure To
Dust And Mold

• Identify possible dust and mold at the work
• Identify possible dust and mold at the work

site and limit exposure
site and limit exposure

• Move work outside whenever possible • Ventilate dusty areas • Use mechanical controls to remove dust
• Move work outside whenever possible
• Ventilate dusty areas
• Use mechanical controls to remove dust

and mold from the air
and mold from the air

• Wear a particulate respirator or dust mask
• Wear a particulate respirator or dust mask

as a last resort
as a last resort

stings

Preventing Insect Stings
Preventing Insect Stings

• Use a stinging insect control aerosol • Make sure not to mow over or disturb a nest • Wear a hat and closed shoes (not sandals). • Light-colored cotton clothing is best. • Avoid heavy, flowery perfumes, or scents. • Avoid sweet beverages, which can attract
• Use a stinging insect control aerosol
• Make sure not to mow over or disturb a nest
• Wear a hat and closed shoes (not sandals).
• Light-colored cotton clothing is best.
• Avoid heavy, flowery perfumes, or scents.
• Avoid sweet beverages, which can attract

stinging insects.
stinging insects.

• Two poisonous spiders you should be

aware of:
aware of:

Preventing Spider Bites

• Shake out clothing or shoes before getting
• Shake out clothing or shoes before getting

• Wear gloves when handling lumber or
• Wear gloves when handling lumber or

• Do not stack wood around a building • Remove vegetation and leaf litter around
• Do not stack wood around a building

dressed
dressed

rocks
rocks

building
building

• Use insect repellants, such as DEET or

Ticks
Ticks

• Working in landscaping, forestry, or brush clearing can be risky because of exposure to ticks.
• Working in landscaping, forestry, or brush
clearing can be risky because of exposure
to ticks.

• Lyme Disease and Rocky Mountain
• Lyme Disease and Rocky Mountain

spotted fever.
spotted fever.

Tick Transmitted Diseases
Tick Transmitted Diseases

Preventing Tick Bites
Preventing Tick Bites

• Stay out of brushy, overgrown grass, and
• Stay out of brushy, overgrown grass, and

• Remove leaves, tall grass, and brush from
• Remove leaves, tall grass, and brush from

wooded habitats
wooded habitats

work areas.
work areas.

• Wear light-colored clothing so ticks may
• Wear light-colored clothing so ticks may

be easily seen and removed before attaching.
be easily seen and removed before
attaching.

• Check your whole body for ticks,
• Check your whole body for ticks,

especially armpits, groin, and pubic areas.
especially armpits, groin, and pubic areas.

Fire Ants
Fire Ants

• Fire ants attack anything that disturbs their mound (nest). • The sting of a fire ant develops
• Fire ants attack anything that
disturbs their mound (nest).
• The sting of a fire ant develops

into a pustule (small, firm blister-like sore) in 24-48 hours. • Be aware – don’t stand on ant nests or areas where they are foraging.
into a pustule (small, firm
blister-like sore) in 24-48 hours.
• Be aware – don’t stand on ant
nests or areas where they are
foraging.

Mosquitoes
Mosquitoes

• Mosquitoes transmit West Nile Virus
• Mosquitoes transmit West Nile Virus

Avoiding Mosquito Exposure
Avoiding Mosquito Exposure

• Stay indoors at dawn and dusk and in the
• Stay indoors at dawn and dusk and in the

early evening, if possible.
early evening, if possible.

• Wear long pants and long sleeves
• Wear long pants and long sleeves

outdoors.
outdoors.

• Use space sprays or aerosol foggers for
• Use space sprays or aerosol foggers for

rapid knockdown of mosquitoes.
rapid knockdown of mosquitoes.

• Eliminate mosquito breeding grounds by
• Eliminate mosquito breeding grounds by

removing stagnant water
removing stagnant water

Venomous Snakes

Rattlesnake
Rattlesnake

Copperhead
Copperhead

Cottonmouth
Cottonmouth

Snake Bite Treatment
Snake Bite Treatment

• The first step in snakebite treatment is to
• The first step in snakebite treatment is to

avoid panic.
avoid panic.

• Keep bite victims still and calm to slow the
• Keep bite victims still and calm to slow the

spread of venom in case the snake is poisonous.
spread of venom in case the snake is
poisonous.

• If bitten, note the color and shape of the
• If bitten, note the color and shape of the

snake to help with treatment.
snake to help with treatment.

• Do not cut the wound or attempt to suck
• Do not cut the wound or attempt to suck

out the venom.
out the venom.

• Avoiding contact
• Avoiding contact

plants
plants

– Recognize the leaf patterns of the poisonous
– Recognize the leaf patterns of the poisonous

Poison Ivy Poison Oak Poison Sumac
Poison Ivy Poison Oak Poison Sumac

Avoiding Cuts/Scratches by Thorn Bushes
Avoiding Cuts/Scratches
by Thorn Bushes

• Always wear gloves. Leather
• Always wear gloves. Leather

gloves are best.
gloves are best.

• Wear a long sleeve shirt and long pants. Clothing made of thicker cloth is better.
• Wear a long sleeve shirt and long
pants. Clothing made of thicker
cloth is better.

• Wear work shoes or boots. Do not wear sandals or open-toed shoes.
• Wear work shoes or boots. Do not
wear sandals or open-toed shoes.

• If you are cutting bushes, wear
• If you are cutting bushes, wear

eye protection and a safety hard hat.
eye protection and a safety hard
hat.

Factors Leading To Heat Stress
Factors Leading To Heat Stress

Danger: Heat Stroke Can Kill!
Danger: Heat Stroke Can Kill!

NIOSH Fatal Fact
NIOSH Fatal Fact

A 30-year old landscape mowing assistant collapsed and died at the end of a day of caring for residential lawns. A typical day’s work consisted of mowing, edging, trimming with a weed whip, and finishing with a back- pack blower.
A 30-year old landscape mowing assistant
collapsed and died at the end of a day of
caring for residential lawns. A typical day’s
work consisted of mowing, edging, trimming
with a weed whip, and finishing with a back-
pack blower.

Cause of death: Heat stroke!
Cause of death: Heat stroke! C a u s e
o f
d e a t h :
H e a t
s t r o k e !

Heat Stress Victim
Heat Stress Victim

Preventing Heat Related Illness • Know signs/symptoms of heat-related illnesses. • Block out direct sun or other heat sources. • Use cooling fans/air-conditioning. • Drink lots of water; about 1 cup every 15
Preventing Heat Related Illness
• Know signs/symptoms of heat-related illnesses.
• Block out direct sun or other heat sources.
• Use cooling fans/air-conditioning.
• Drink lots of water; about 1 cup every 15

minutes.
minutes.

• Wear lightweight, light colored,
• Wear lightweight, light colored,

loose-fitting clothes.
loose-fitting clothes.

• Avoid alcohol, caffeinated drinks, or
• Avoid alcohol, caffeinated drinks, or

heavy meals.
heavy meals.

• Rest periodically in a cool area.
• Rest periodically in a cool area.

Sun Exposure
Sun Exposure

• Too much sun can cause severe burns • While working in the sun wear:
• Too much sun can cause severe burns
• While working in the sun wear:

– Sleeves and long pants as a barrier to the
– Sleeves and long pants as a barrier to the

– A wide-brimmed hat for head and face
– A wide-brimmed hat for head and face

sun
sun

protection
protection

– A sunscreen with at least SPF 15, reapply
– A sunscreen with at least SPF 15, reapply

every 2 hours
every 2 hours

– Sunglasses to protect the eyes
– Sunglasses to protect the eyes

Cold Stress
Cold Stress

• The harmful effects of hypothermia,
• The harmful effects of hypothermia, • T h e
h a r m f u l
e f f e c t s
o f
h y p o t h e r m i a ,

frostbite, and trench foot may arise for any worker exposed to high winds and cold temperatures.
frostbite, and trench foot may arise for f r o s t b i t e ,
a n d
t r e n c h
f o o t m a y
a r i s e
f o r
any worker exposed to high winds and cold
temperatures.

• Wet conditions exacerbate these effects. • Hypothermia (body temp. at or below 95°F) – Symptoms: Fatigue, uncontrolled shivering, slurred speech, irritable, bluish skin, clumsy.
• Wet conditions exacerbate these effects.
• Hypothermia (body temp. at or below 95°F)
– Symptoms: Fatigue, uncontrolled shivering,
slurred speech, irritable, bluish skin, clumsy.

Preventing Cold Stress
Preventing Cold Stress

• Personal protective clothing (three layers)
• Personal protective clothing (three layers)

– Outside layer to block the wind – Middle layer of wool or synthetic fabric – Inner layer of cotton to allow ventilation – Cover hands and face and wear a hat
– Outside layer to block the wind
– Middle layer of wool or synthetic fabric
– Inner layer of cotton to allow ventilation
– Cover hands and face and wear a hat

• Use an on-site source of heat, such as air
• Use an on-site source of heat, such as air

jets, radiant heaters, or contact warm plates.
jets, radiant heaters, or contact warm
plates.
